question: <image 1> What circumstances lead to the typical downy growth showing up on the bottom surface of a leaf from a grapevine that's infected with downy mildew, given that this is the top surface of such a leaf?
options: ['Low temperature; low light', 'When free water has splashed up onto the underside of the leaf', 'High temperature, high light', 'High relative humidity', "I don't know and I don't want to guess"]
description: The image shows a close-up view of a grapevine leaf with visible signs of downy mildew infection. The leaf exhibits characteristic symptoms of downy mildew, including yellowish-green spots and patches on the upper surface. These spots are irregularly shaped and scattered across the leaf, indicating the presence of the disease. The leaf veins are prominently visible, and the overall texture of the leaf appears slightly distorted due to the infection. The background includes other leaves, some of which also show signs of discoloration and damage, suggesting a widespread infection in the plant.
